title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the US dollar on 30 November 2018?
preds: Question ends tomorrow so I guess I'm  going all in on 5.00-6.00.

Current ratio is 5.29TRY/USD and falling at rate of 0.013 Lira/day for the past month. This continues a downward trend that started around 18 September. Continuing this would mean losses of .11 Lira over the next 8 days, putting it at 5.18 on 30 Nov. In order for the distribution to flip, we would need to see a price shift similar to that between 9-14 Aug 2018 from ~5.3 - ~6.9 when Trump announced doubling tariffs on steel and aluminum imported from Turkey. However, the price has been extremely volatile in local shifts. The mean of the projection may be ~5.2, but the variance could put it below 5.

After the lira strengthened recently on possible extradition of Gulen to Turkey, Trump announced he is not considering such a move. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-17/trump-says-he-isn-t-considering-extraditing-gulen-to-turkey

Further update with time, still using Gaussian curve ...
Mean 5.45 -> 5.32 (adjusting for current TRY:USD value).
SD 0.4 -> 0.3 (reflecting decreased time before question closes).

I assert that mostly likely the closing value for the Turkish lira against the US dollar on Nov. 30 will be between 5.00 and 6.00 inclusive. According to Pound Sterling Live's U.S. Dollar to Turkish Lira Spot Exchange Rates (https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/bank-of-england-spot/historical-spot-exchange-rates/usd/USD-to-TRY-2018), the current spot exchange rate is 5.368 as of Nov. 15. From the beginning of the month to now the spot exchange rate as fluctuated around 5.4-5.5 approximately. Moreover, if we look at the past couple years around this time, we do not see extreme fluctuations of the spot exchange rate (2017 saw the spot exchange rate hover around 3.85 for November). Due to past trends and the fact that we are already half way through the month of November, I assert that the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the US dollar will be between 5.00 and 6.00, inclusive.

I contend that the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the US dollar on 30 November 2018 will be between 5.00 and 6.00, inclusive. My assessment is grounded in my analysis of the spot rate of the lira-dollar exchange rate for the last five years, recorded by Bloomberg (https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDTRY:CUR). The spot exchange rate currently is 5.5013 (accurate as of 13 November 10:20).  In a five year span, the spot exchange rate has only fluctuated equal to or greater than a half a percentage point within a month span in July-August 2018. The spot exchange rate in a five year span has stabilized in November of each year, with the exception of 2016, fluctuating no more than 0.33 points. We can expect that the spot exchange rate will stabilize in November 2018, as it has historically done the last few years, including the first half of November 2018 as it has only fluctuated 0.03 points. Lastly, the spot exchange rate has remained between 5.00 and 6.00 since early October 2018. Therefore, I conclude, with a high degree of certainty, that the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the US dollar on 30 November will be between 5.00 and 6.00, inclusive.

Once again, too slow on the updates. Still using a gaussian curve (for want of any better tool to quantify and analyse my assumptions) ...
Mean 5.45 (current TRY:USD value).
SD 0.4 (reflecting decreased time before question closes).

Since the lira fell by more than 40% this year in addition to the tariffs imposed by the United States, the lira has yet  to fully recover currently hovering at about 5.5 on October 31st. Therefore I think it is likely that the lira may continue to recover but will not reach below 5 by the end of November.

The currency has stabilized better than I thought it would, although I still think the currency has significant downside risks.

Ugh.  I've screwed the pooch on this forecast, letting it sit unattended for so long. Current rate is 5.59; using ASSUMPTION ONE, that means that the median probability will be about 5.60 in 6wk time. Playing with a bell curve calculator (https://www.easycalculation.com/statistics/bell-curve-calculator.php), using a mean of 5.6, and a SD of 0.75 (which is a rough approximation of how broad I think the probability distribution will be), I get the above results. (And yes, I do accept Taleb's hypothesis that currency, stock, and commodity price movements are not subject to the "tame probability" that is assumed by a symmetrical Gaussian distribution ... but at least this is a start!)
Right now, the lira is the strongest it's been in the past weeks.
Yup youre right. Trendline us favorable.
+7 percentage points. Lira continued to strengthen today, vindicating my hypothesis that the release of U.S. pastor is bullish for the currency.

My position is that it is merely a question WHEN the Lira will pass 7, NOT IF.
I am not an options trader and a specific exchange rate forecast on a given day in the future is purely speculative.
If the Turkish Fed comes up with the outlandish idea to raise its rate to, say 35%, risk conscious speculants will buy Lira like there is no tomorrow. On the other hand, the Kleptokrat might start some war, hopefully merely with words, if at all, and the Lira will continue its dive.
So far my 2 cents worth of a reasoning behind my speculation.
I would not bet any more real money than those 2 cents on any single answer.

Brunson was reportedly released [1], which I had previously assigned a 45% probability to. So this is making me revise down.  Aside from the immediate implications: possibility that the U.S. will ease sanctions (which was the catalyst behind the run up of the lira as I wrote initially: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/766814), this is also a sign that Erdogan is taking a pragmatic approach toward the currency crisis. Though he seems to harbor deep resentment against the U.S. (thinking it was behind the failed coup), the fact that he was willing to back down suggests that he is genuinely interested in diffusing the situation quickly.  This raises the chances that he will let the central bank raise rates again at its upcoming meeting on Oct 25, which should strengthen the lira further. [1] http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-court-issues-andrew-brunson-ruling-release-137825
News says the American Pastor on house arrest in rural Turkey is being released, which will end sanctions and ease pressure on the Lira.

I am tempering my expectation for further weakening of the lira ahead of the Oct 12 hearing for the US Pastor. There are some signs that he might be released. An anonymous Turkish official said it was a possibility. The US has laid off of Turkey in the last few weeks, giving Turkey some space to release him while saving face. [1] Still, as I wrote earlier [2], the tensions between the US and Turkey are deep, which makes me question the release and assume it is slightly more likely that it won't happen (~55%). Even if it did, it is not guaranteed that the marker reaction will be strong enough to place the lira under 6 by 30 Nov. A probability of a release is already partially priced in the market and Turkey has economic problems other than the US sanctions  (squeezed public budgets, looming debt repayments, loose monetary policy). [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/hopes-rise-for-release-of-u-s-pastor-being-held-in-turkey-1537742415
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/766814

Shifting more toward >6 and >7 As expected, the weaker lira is translating into inflation for consumers as measured by the CPI (Consumer Price Index). Interestingly, however, the PPI (producer price index) has gone up even more significantly (twice as much as the CPI on an year-on-year basis) [1]. The PPI usually front-runs the CPI (because businesses eventually pass through cost increases on consumers) so these numbers suggest the CPI is probably going to get worse in the coming months. This would further cramp the ability of consumers to repay loans, put upward pressure on interest rates, and further alienate investors (leading to lower demand for the lira). Much of this is probably already priced in. Further, the IMF [2] suggests Turkey's troubles are far from over with next year GDP numbers slashed to what is essentially projected to be a stagnation.  Technical traders are probably going to look at the 50 day moving average (around 6) and see it as a price support. I wouldn't be surprised if algorithm traders have set this level as an automatic buy zone for the USD/TRY exchange rate (suggesting lower likelihood of the exchange rate being below 6, i.e. a lower likelihood of the lira strengthening). Events to look out for [1]:
- Oct 12: court hearing for U.S. pastor Andrew Brunson’s (possible release, which would strengthen the lira)
- Oct 25: central bank meeting Sources:
[1] https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/watch-out-turkish-lira
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-09/imf-says-crisis-scarred-turkey-needs-to-go-all-in-to-fix-economy

Exchange rate is at 6.0323TRY very close to the border between the middle two buckets. Heroic Erdgoans decree outlawing the indexing of real estate to dollar funding should eliminate the need for dollars. And increase the demand for lira. Killing two birds with one stone and having the return stone clean, dress and cook the birds.  Turkey to use national currency in trade with Russia
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/turkey-to-use-national-currency-in-trade-with-russia/1270715 Iran, Russia, Turkey to Ditch US Dollar in Trade 
https://www.albawaba.com/business/iran-russia-turkey-ditch-us-dollar-trade-1183412 Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov told reporters:  “The use of national currencies for mutual trade has for several years been one of the tasks that the presidents of Russia and Turkey had set. Not only with Turkey and Iran, we’re also arranging and already implementing payments in national currencies with the People’s Republic of China. I am confident that the grave abuse of the role of the U.S. dollar as a global reserve currency will result over time in the weakening and demise of its role."

Better US and EU relations, key Turkish bank getting a big loan. It looks like everything is going in the right direction. US needs a stable Turkish economy to stabilize their military ally politically, EU needs to save Spanish and Italian banks from Turkish defaults so 7+ is unlikely now unless Erdogan really screws his country over with some crazy move. I'd be tempted to bet even more at sub 6.00 but I will wait for a correction after the strengthening and observe other emerging markets

We are seeing a lessening of investors fears about a potential implosion of the Turkish market. This shows both on the value of the currency (now at 6.00) and on the yield that foreign investors demand from TR lenders. Moreover there have been indications that TR is able to find  short term from foreign governments to smooth out the turbulence. Finally the decree by which all domestic deals will have to be in Lira seems to not have caused too much o a stir. The structural problems remain though, banks are under pressure because of non performing loans. The central bank displayed independence with the interest rate hikes despite Erdogan's objections, but this, coupled with the doubts on finmin's capabilities will highlight the internal tensions and keep alarms sounding. In any case it seems that increasing the value of the Lira is a priority for the government, so I shifted my prediction towards 5:00 to 6:00
Shifting toward 6-7 because of recent Turkish central bank actions that raised rates and seems to have stabilized the situation.

A quick bit of frequency analysis based on % movements for 66 day periods (which is what we have until 30 Nov) shows the following frequencies: 14%+ (7+) 32%
-3% to 14% (6-7) 62%
-19% to -3% (5-6) 6% However, a bit of reading suggests an interesting situation in Turkey relating to the "Impossible Trinity" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impossible_trinity) which suggests that countries can't fix their foreign exchange rates, domestic interest rates and capital inflows/outflows from the country, one or more of the factors have to be able to fluctuate based on market conditions. Historically, Turkey has received significant foreign investment which seems to be reversing, resulting in high capital outflows from the country (from the Wikipedia article and associated links https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_currency_and_debt_crisis,_2018#cite_note-18, https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-economy/turkish-current-account-gap-widens-portfolio-inflows-slump). These outflows involve people selling Turkish investments and Turkish Lira to convert their money back to their domestic currency (USD, EUR etc), the selling reduces the value of the Lira. The Government can make the currency more attractive for investors by increasing the interest rates which is the typical path to offset capital outflows and declining currency values. However, Erdoğan seems firmly (and strangely) against raising interest rates (Erdoğan has significant power over the Turkish Central Bank's monetary policy) which suggest that the outflows will be offset by a decline in Lira .  There seems to be a sort of negative feedback loop in that financial institutions make up a significant portion of the Turkish stock market. Capital outflows result in less funds available for borrowing which means that Turkish business that have borrowed find it harder to repay debt. Higher debt defaults lead to poorer performance from the finance sector of the stockmarket which probably results in more capital withdrawals from the country.  Also, the USD seems to be performing well against a trade weighted index, plus outlook is for USD interest rate increases, putting more pressure on the Lira USD. Hence, I've increased the probability of greater (7+) Lira/USD values.

Gains from last week's larger-than-expected Turkish interest rate hike have been all but eliminated this week (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-18/turkish-lira-slides-for-third-day-as-rate-hike-euphoria-fades). Despite the need for higher interest rates, dramatic shifts are bound to have adverse effects. Despite the inevitable up-and-down as Turkey flails to control its skyrocketing inflation and the Turkish bank exercises at least some independence, Erdogan's contempt for basic economic theory and growing uncertainty with US-Turkish relations will to moderate any gains that the bank can achieve, as key international investors continue to worry about Erdogan's policy choices and domestic investors demand more US dollars (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency/turkish-lira-flat-after-rate-hike-gains-investors-look-to-government-plan-idUSKCN1LU0FL; https://www.thechicagocouncil.org/blog/global-insight/deep-dish-turkish-lira-crisis).
Increasing between 5 and 6  by 5% to 29% and and decreaing 7 or more from 25% to 20% based on https://tradingeconomics.com/turkey/currency/forecast
Trending negative right now, the US may want to apply pressure on Turkey as Idlib escalates however.

Nations fail when they have weak institutions. The Turkish presidency has been undermining institutions on all aspects of civic life and a downturn in the long term will be hard to avoid. Last few days the Turkish presidency has taken further steps on the control of media, showing its lack of confidence which should be reflected on the value of the currency. Moreover today (14 September) the central bank of the country hiked the interest rates to 24%. It is a bold move that might tackle inflation but still it shows panic.

6.1310TRY
+0.0489+0.80% “This massive rate hike is going to stabilize the Turkish lira,” said Bernd Berg, a strategist at Woodman Asset Management AG in Zug, Switzerland. “With a central bank that has gained in credibility by showing its independence, Turkish assets are poised to recover in the short-term.” The Borsa Istanbul 100 Index rebounded, rising as much as 1.8 percent led by Turkiye Garanti Bankasi AS and Akbank TAS, the nation’s largest listed lenders. But the rally offered little comfort to thousands of businesses now struggling to come to grips with the snap restrictions on foreign currencies, which his government has yet to explain. t’s common in Turkey, a country that’s long struggled to contain inflation, to index prices in contracts for everything from cars to legal services. About half of the Turkish banking system’s deposits are in foreign currencies and companies have racked up $330 billion in foreign debt, leaving a foreign-exchange shortfall of $216 billion.

Adjusting on the rate rise by the central bank.

An important reason for the dramatic decline of the lira is the increasing influence of President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan on the central bank, which has been troubling international investors for months. The banking supervision of the European Central Bank (ECB) has been looking for weeks at those banks that have lent in Turkey loans. Especially French, Italian and Spanish institutions are affected. For example, the Spanish banking sector has 80, the French banking sector 35 and the German banks 17 billion, according to data from the Bank for International Settlements. A further devaluation will not take place.

Threatening it buys a few days - but look for a huge move if there's no concrete significant action Sep 13.

Mostly a wild ass guess based on the assumption that futures prices have already processed most of the available information with predictive value.  I didn't bother actually looking at historical accuracy of futures prices at the 2 month point which likely would improve the guesses at standard deviation.  In this case I'm assuming greater error in the upward direction due to the historical nature of currency crises in corrupt governments.
Adjusting slightly toward higher TYR/USD numbers on latest news https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/30/turkish-lira-sinks-after-reports-that-a-key-central-bank-member-could-resign.html
THis is gonna be a train wreck.

Currently rate = 6.81. Continue to assume a rise or fall from here are equally likely (though the price is changing rapidly presently, so will need to recheck when I wake in the morning). IF rate falls, 12:5:1 that will [fall <0.81] : [fall between 0.81 and 1.81] : [fall more than 1.81]. 
IF rate rises, 1:4 that will [rise <0.19] : [rise 0.19+]. So ... 
p(rate <5.00) = 0.50 * 0.06 = 0.0277 
p(rate 5-6) = 0.50 * 0.28 = 0.1388 
p(rate 6-7) = (0.50 * 0.67) + (0.50 * 0.20) = 0.4333 
p(rate 7+) = 0.50 * 0.80 = 0.4000

I recalculated the odds using a revised version of the Monte Carlo model I created (described here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/766814)  This time the model samples % daily changes in price from a normal distribution with a mean equal to the average change over the period July 9-Aug 27 (picked somewhat arbitrarily to represent the period of the currency crisis). The average is equal to a 0.8% change increase in the price. Results:
<5: 1%
5-6:  3%
6-7: 8%
>7: 88% This is a far from perfect model as it uses limited data (+ the fact that currency crises probably do not conform to normal distributions). However, what I draw from this is the following: if we assume that the situation continues to unravel the way it has, it is very difficult to justify a forecast below 6. To do so, we'd have to believe that the Turkish government will take steps to alleviate the problems. As I've written before (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/766955), raising rates seems unlikely and fiscal measures will probably be limited. There is a chance, however, that the tensions with the U.S. will ease, which would be bullish for the lira. That is why I raise the percentage for <6 from the Monte Carlo results.  Second, model results can be useful when they show you something that surprises you. In this case, the chance of >7 seems surprisingly high. This is to a large extent due to the fact that the model does not capture any kind of balancing feedbacks (a very weak currency might force the government to take stronger measures), so it's easy for the results to be so dramatic. It is also questionable to assume that, on average, the price will keep changing as it has since July 9. Nevertheless, the model provides useful information as to the amount of uncertainty we can expect. The results here and the previous results in my original post show that given the high recent volatility, it is difficult to see the price ending within the relatively tight window of 6-7 (unless one has a reason to believe that volatility will change significantly). So this is making me increase the odds of >7 slightly.

Currently rate = 6.27.  Continue to assume a rise or fall from here are equally likely. IF rate falls, 6:6:1 that will [fall <0.27] : [fall between 0.27 and 1.27] : fall more than 1.27].
IF rate rises, 2:1 that will [rise <0.73] : [rise 0.73+]. So ... 
p(rate <5.00) = 0.50 * 0.07 = 0.0350 
p(rate 5-6) = 0.50 * 0.46 = 0.2300 
p(rate 6-7) = (0.50 * 0.46) + (0.50 * 0.67) = 0.5650
p(rate 7+) = 0.50 * 0.33 = 0.1650

I am revising my original forecast (see my initial rationale here [1]) after I learned that Erdogan harbors rather idiosyncratic economic views. He has a long-standing belief that higher interest rates cause inflation rather than cure it [2]. This makes it much less likely than I originally assumed that he will let the central bank (which is under his control) raise rates (which is the standard macroeconomist prescription to such predicaments. It is for example believed to have gotten Argentina out of their recent currency crisis).  Therefore, one of the main short term fixes that could have boosted the lira is very unlikely to take place. This makes me think that the probability of the lira strengthening from here is much lower. Turkey could still respond to the crisis with fiscal measures but given their high borrowing costs and maturing debt, this might be only a partial solution. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/766814
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-15/erdogan-s-40-year-old-theory-of-inflation-scores-a-win-in-turkey

Updating because my initial forecast screwed up the direction (I just have to accept I will never internalize currency movement and conversion). Anyway my underlying logic is the same: While the price right now is 6.1688 and the lira's slide against the dollar has stabilized in the last week, this feels like a temporary calm more than the end of the crisis. This is because the underlying factors (link 1) that led to the lira's slide, economic mismanagement, interference in the central bank, and the trade dispute with the US, haven't gone away. It is only because Qatar announced it was going to invest $15 billion in Turkey on Aug 15 (link 2) that the slide has stopped for the moment. Unless other countries are going to keep dropping money in Turkey, that provides only temporary relief and the lira will begin to slide again due to underlying factors. https://www.economist.com/leaders/2018/08/18/how-much-to-worry-about-turkeys-turmoil
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-currency-qatar-investments/qatar-to-invest-15-billion-in-turkey-source-says-banks-the-focus-idUSKBN1L01P7

This got a bit long so I have organized it in sections: ~~~
Introduction
~~~ The lira has fallen over the past few months due to a number of factors (as always, "nothing happens for a reason, everything happens for lots of reasons"):
* sanctions by the U.S. over a dispute about the release of the American pastor Andrew Brunson, who Turkey accuses of espionage. The tensions between the U.S. and Turkey run deep. Erdogan entertains the suspicion that the U.S. was behind the failed coup attempt in 2016 and holds a grudge against the U.S. refusal to extradite Fethullah Gulen
* underlying economic conditions that primed the currency for a potential fall
   - a long period of low interest rates that had overheated the economy, leading to inflation
   - a current account deficit (Turkey borrows in order to import more than it exports). 
   - impending near term load repayments. Turkey has $100 billion in loans maturing over the next year. Since they'd have to sell lira and buy USD to service the loans, that puts pressure on the currency
* US Fed raising rates, causing the dollar to appreciate against other currencies (including an impending very likely Sept rate hike)
* All resulting in reinforcing feedback loops
   - Turkish banks now have to borrow at higher rates, which raises concerns for their ability to pay back down the road. Higher interest rates lead to tighter credit conditions within the Turkish economy, which slows it down, putting more pressure on the lira
Sources: See, e.g. [1, 2, 3]  Given the underlying reasons mentioned above, this is a question mainly of policy and politics. A recent recovery has taken place since August 13 and the lira currently stands at ~6.1 TYR/USD. This price represents the market view of the impacts of all of the known factors mentioned above in addition to the market's assigned probabilities of near-term events. So whether and how the price changes from this number, depends on how the unknown factors (see Inside View below) shake out (note that although some events happen in the future, such as the Sept rate hike and Turkey's maturing loans, those are probably already priced in and that there is little uncertainty about them so I don' think they will be decisive factors). ~~~
Outside view
~~~ I built a Monte Carlo (MC) model to try to estimate the uncertainty in where the price could end up by end November (=65 working days of trading). I took historical daily USD/TYR data [4] from July 9 to today. July 9 is an arbitrary choice for roughly when the market started showing significant signs of turmoil based on [5]. Alternative model formulations could include alternative timelines.  I built a normal distribution using the standard deviation of the daily % changes (this equaled 3.4). I assumed an average of 0 (equally likely for the price to go down as up). I then perform MC simulations (10,000 iterations), which start with the current price  (6.1), sample from the distribution of % daily price changes, add them to the price, and estimate a final Nov 30 price. Finally, I get a distribution from the 10,000 outcomes from the MC. Results:
<5: 28% of outcomes fell here
5-6: 24%
6-7: 21%
7: 27% Conclusion so far: if one uses the recent currency volatility as an indication for the volatility up to Nov 30, we should expect a wide range of outcomes. It could be instructive to consider doing this MC analysis using other timeframes, or using data from other currency crises as an estimate for a reasonable currency volatility (i.e. standard deviation to assume in the model). e.g. from this paper [6] ~~~
Inside view
~~~ Unknown factors that will decide the outcome include:
* Decisions by Turkey and/or the U.S. on the release/extradition of Brunson and/or Gulen
* Turkey's fiscal and monetary policy response
* Market sentiment - traders might over/under-react. A particular event could trigger a reinforcing feedback loop leading to an across-the-board selling of the lira. Alternatively, the market could underreact to improving economic circumstances in Turkey as trust in the financial stability and credit-worthiness might take time to be restored (financial crises take longer to resolve than other economic predicaments). The first uncertainty concerns a battle of egos between Erdogan and Trump. The popular perception of Erdogan is that he doesn't back down but he did take a soft stance when Turkey downed a Russian jet. Trump similarly softened on North Korea even though they only offered minor concessions. From Trump's perspective, the U.S. should be worried about threat of economic contagion from a down falling Turkey as well as Turkey aligning itself more closely with Russia. From Erdogan's perspective, the spat with Trump gives him a scapegoat to pin the blame to, which appears to be working to some extent: in a recent survey 42 percent blamed foreign governments for  Turkey's problems and only 36 percent said it was the AKP government [1]. Erdogan is expending a lot of effort to keep the Turkish public on his side, traveling the country, giving up to three speeches per day [7] and his grip on the media helps him turn the public against the U.S. However, the economic turmoil does hurt his popularity according to recent surveys quoted here [1].  So, both sides would benefit from a mutual face-saving resolution but Erdogan has an incentive to keep it going and Trump may not be sensitive to the economic and geopolitical (Russia alignment by Turkey) consequences. It is hard to come up with a probability but in the courageous style of Fermi, I am guesstimating and assume a 30% likelihood before end Nov. A resolution would probably have a significant effect on the price and market sentiment as it has been one of the main drivers lately. However, it wouldn't solve all of Turkey's underlying economic problems so I am guessing it would place the price just above 5. A lack of resolution would probably induce a slow rise in the lira. The second factor is a more likely source of bullishness for the Lira. Allowing a raise of interest rates would help boost the currency. Erdogan has to consider the fact that a currency crisis could cause him to loose his position. A leader is 70% more likely to lose his post in the six months following a currency crisis [8]. He supposedly wants to stay in power and allowing rates to rise would be an obvious way to alleviate economic burdens and claim credit with the public. The central bank has already implemented a back door tightening by making banks borrow at slightly higher rates. However, no other specific fiscal or monetary measures are on the horizon yet; from today's FT: "In previous statements, including a conference call two weeks ago with investors, Mr Albayrak has vowed to take measures to shore up the Turkish economy. But he has refrained from giving any indication that monetary tightening — something that many analysts see as critical to propping up the lira — is on the horizon." It will be important to watch the publication of Turkey’s medium-term program for the economy, which Finance minister Albayrak said he would announce in the first half of September. All in all, I am assuming that some sort of stimulus is probable (say 65%) Third, market sentiment and reactions to existing information might still be ongoing (meaning that the market has yet to fully price in the crisis). This suggests a higher likelihood of a lower lira as the market continues to price in the economic risks and as feedback loops (credit crunch hurting the economy, further tightening credit) are playing out. Conclusions: a lack of resolution to the dispute with the US skews the outcome in bearish direction (i.e. lira ending lower than current levels). However, a potential economic stimulus would do the opposite. These two counteracting factors increase the likelihood of the price staying closer to current levels rather than farther away. I am therefore increasing the chances of 5-7 relative to the tails from what I estimated with the MC analysis above. A slight lean toward 6-7 and >7 reflects the potential that market sentiment and economic feedback loops could continue to unravel to the detriment of the lira. No fancy spreadsheets here - the prior data for USD:TRY is not really relevant in this situation.  So let's break it down stepwise ... ASSUMPTION ONE
The "wisdom of the crowd" means that the current price is the best guess for the price going forwards - the mean estimate, if not the median.  With the current price of 6.01, and an overall long-term tendency for the rate to slowly increase with time, I estimate that it is about 55:45 that the price on 30 November will be above:below 6.00. ASSUMPTION TWO
It is very difficult to imagine a situation where there is sufficient good news (for Turkey) in a short space of time sufficient to push the rate back below 5.00.  Thing had been looking shaky BEFORE the recent confrontation with the USA, and the price has been persistently above 4.00 since early April, and at or above 4.50 since mid-May.  Thus, IF the rate falls from here, it is MUCH more likely that the rate will still remain above 5.00.  Let's call this 10:1. ASSUMPTION THREE
At the peak of the panic two weeks ago, the price jumped JUST above 7.00.  For the rate to exceed 7.00 on 30 November, the "situation" would have to be even worse than the pessimistic views on 13 August.  This is UNLIKELY, but is more likely than the idea that the situation will improve to being better for Turkey than it has been for many months (ie. a rate under 5.00).  Thus, IF the rate rises from here, it is more likely that the rate will not exceed 7.00.  Let's call this 4:1. So ...
p(rate <5.00) = 0.45 * 0.09 = 0.0405
p(rate 5-6) = 0.45 * 0.91 = 0.4095
p(rate 6-7) = 0.55 * 0.80 = 0.4400
p(rate 7+) = 0.55 * 0.20 = 0.1100

While the price right now is 6.1040 and the lira's slide against the dollar has stabilized in the last week, this feels like a temporary calm more than the end of the crisis. This is because the underlying factors (link 1) that led to the lira's slide, economic mismanagement, interference in the central bank, and the trade dispute with the US, haven't gone away. It is only because Qatar announced it was going to invest $15 billion in Turkey on Aug 15 (link 2) that the slide has stopped for the moment. Unless other countries are going to keep dropping money in Turkey, that provides only temporary relief and the lira will begin to slide again due to underlying factors. https://www.economist.com/leaders/2018/08/18/how-much-to-worry-about-turkeys-turmoil

President Erdogan will try to secure economic wealth and therefore agree to compromises.
Fed Rate increase in September will put even more pressure on the lira.   Erdogan isn't the kind of person to back down.
